Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2013
Award.AbstractNarration:
The role of the water channel aquaglyceroporin-3b (Aqp-3b) in cellular dynamics during early nervous system development and neural tube closure


During early embryonic development, changes in the shape and placement of cells causes the neural plate to form the neural tube. Transcription factors like Zic1 in the neural plate direct the expression of genes that regulate cellular behavior during neural tube closure. While previous work has identified aquaglyceroporin-3b (aqp-3b), a water channel, as a downstream target of Zic factors, little is known about how aqp-3b affects nervous system development. The zebrafish model system will be used to determine the role of Aqp-3b during changes in cell shape and adhesion as the neural plate forms the neural tube. The goal of this project is to use the genetic and optical assets of the zebrafish embryo to study the closure of the neural tube, a developmental event that has far-reaching consequences for normal nervous system development.

The training goals of this project are to provide experience in early nervous system developmental research conducted across species and to provide experience with developing undergraduate education. The education goals of this project involve using the rapid development and genetic accessibility of the zebrafish as a tool to integrate undergraduate instruction with molecular research. Aspects of this project will be developed into a course for American Indian tribal college students to introduce biological research and to create a lasting positive effect on their future participation in the field of developmental biology and neuroscience. This research-based course will expose students early in their biology careers to research with the goal of increasing their future success in STEM fields.

ProgramReference.Text: BIO MINORITY POSTDOC RESEARCH FELLOW PGM

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of our project was to investigate a developmental role for Aquaglyceroporin-3b (Aqp3b), a membrane channel protein that allows the passive passage of water and other small molecules into and out of cells. Historically aquaporins have well-established roles in adult organisms as main components of urine concentration in the kidneys and as part of the machinery of wound closure. Yet, the field of developmental biology lacks established roles for Aquaporins in developing embryos and our project had significant intellectual merit by discovering a previously unknown role for Aquaporins.  Our lab found an Aquaglyceroporin that is developmentally expressed in the frog Xenopus laevis. Using frog and zebrafish embryos as a model, we investigated this developmental role further and discovered a novel role for Aqp3b during gastrulating embryo and neural tube closure.

                  As part of this project, we studied the essential development step of gastrulation. During this time, a blastula embryo, which has one single layer of tissue surrounding an internal space, becomes a multilayered gastrula stage embryo via the movements of cells into the embryo. Essential to this proses is the delineation between tissues and the coordinated movements of cells that compose those tissues. Our lab has discovered that during gastrulation Aqp3b is essential for the formation of the Fibronectin protein barrier that separates the newly formed tissues in the gastrula embryos. Fibronectin is an extracellular protein that can link to form a matrix. This matrix is important for the tissue architecture of the developing embryos. In our experiments, the loss of the FN matrix resulted in the disruption of the movements of cells within the gastrula stage embryo. 

           During nervous system formation, our MO experiments have demonstrated that Aqp3b is required for neural tube closure. To further our investigation, we focused on determining if Aqp3b has a role in convergence and extension (CE). CE occurs both during neural tube closure and gastrulation to help from the embryo. Using a variety of methods, our goal was to determine when and where Aqp3b functions to facilitate CE. We found that both during gastrulation and closure of the neural tube, Aqp3b is important for the CE of the developing embryos and a loss in CE resulted in a reduction in the CE movement of cells during gastrulation, a disruption in the closure of the neural tube, and shorter body length as the embryo aged. Also, an interesting part of these findings is that Aqp3b appears to be important for signaling pathways that are responsible for the CE movements. 

          Part of broader impacts of this project also involves the development and execution of a research-based course that aims to increase the participation of American Indians in STEM research. American Indians face significant obstacles and lack the opportunity to participate in undergraduate research. We believe that to increase the participation of America Indians in STEM research we needed to provide students with an initial exposure that would ignite interest and also train them for future involvement. Our program tries to alleviate challenges faced by American Indian students, by bringing a traveling research course to Tribal Colleges.

             Our course used an innovative teaching technique involving experiments with live zebrafish embryos acting as a model organism. Each student developed and conducted experiments that studied how different conditions and substances like drugs and alcohol affect the development of the zebrafish embryos. Students were able to watch embryos develop from one cell eggs to swimming larvae; while, simultaneously make the cognitive connection between their experiments and the development of a human fetus exposed to compounds like alcohol. Since fish health is also an indicator of environmental contamination, students also tested how local water samples affected zebrafish development. This development was documented using tools and methods used in cutting-edge research and these data was then presented by the student to the community at large. While we strived to provide research skills, we also sought to impart to the students a research mindset that would continue to serve the students. The course was conducted for 3 years consecutively at 5 different sites, Including Montana state university (Bozeman, Mt), Chief Dull Knife College (Lame Deer, Mt), Little Big Horn College (Crow Agency), Fort Peck Community College (Poplar, Mt) and Aaniiih Nakoda College (Fort Belknap, Mt). The course also offers the opportunity to build a network between Montana State University and the surrounding Tribal Colleges in Montana. This network serves to support students as they transition from Tribal Colleges to Montana State University.  

 


Last Modified: 03/29/2018
Modified by: Jennifer B Forecki
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The major goal of our project was to investigate a developmental role for Aquaglyceroporin-3b (Aqp3b), a membrane channel protein that allows the passive passage of water and other small molecules into and out of cells. Historically aquaporins have well-established roles in adult organisms as main components of urine concentration in the kidneys and as part of the machinery of wound closure. Yet, the field of developmental biology lacks established roles for Aquaporins in developing embryos and our project had significant intellectual merit by discovering a previously unknown role for Aquaporins. Our lab found an Aquaglyceroporin that is developmentally expressed in the frog Xenopus laevis. Using frog and zebrafish embryos as a model, we investigated this developmental role further and discovered a novel role for Aqp3b during gastrulating embryo and neural tube closure. As part of this project, we studied the essential development step of gastrulation. During this time, a blastula embryo, which has one single layer of tissue surrounding an internal space, becomes a multilayered gastrula stage embryo via the movements of cells into the embryo. Essential to this proses is the delineation between tissues and the coordinated movements of cells that compose those tissues. Our lab has discovered that during gastrulation Aqp3b is essential for the formation of the Fibronectin protein barrier that separates the newly formed tissues in the gastrula embryos. Fibronectin is an extracellular protein that can link to form a matrix. This matrix is important for the tissue architecture of the developing embryos. In our experiments, the loss of the FN matrix resulted in the disruption of the movements of cells within the gastrula stage embryo. During nervous system formation, our MO experiments have demonstrated that Aqp3b is required for neural tube closure. To further our investigation, we focused on determining if Aqp3b has a role in convergence and extension (CE). CE occurs both during neural tube closure and gastrulation to help from the embryo. Using a variety of methods, our goal was to determine when and where Aqp3b functions to facilitate CE. We found that both during gastrulation and closure of the neural tube, Aqp3b is important for the CE of the developing embryos and a loss in CE resulted in a reduction in the CE movement of cells during gastrulation, a disruption in the closure of the neural tube, and shorter body length as the embryo aged. Also, an interesting part of these findings is that Aqp3b appears to be important for signaling pathways that are responsible for the CE movements. Part of broader impacts of this project also involves the development and execution of a research-based course that aims to increase the participation of American Indians in STEM research. American Indians face significant obstacles and lack the opportunity to participate in undergraduate research. We believe that to increase the participation of America Indians in STEM research we needed to provide students with an initial exposure that would ignite interest and also train them for future involvement. Our program tries to alleviate challenges faced by American Indian students, by bringing a traveling research course to Tribal Colleges. Our course used an innovative teaching technique involving experiments with live zebrafish embryos acting as a model organism. Each student developed and conducted experiments that studied how different conditions and substances like drugs and alcohol affect the development of the zebrafish embryos. Students were able to watch embryos develop from one cell eggs to swimming larvae; while, simultaneously make the cognitive connection between their experiments and the development of a human fetus exposed to compounds like alcohol. Since fish health is also an indicator of environmental contamination, students also tested how local water samples affected zebrafish development. This development was documented using tools and methods used in cutting-edge research and these data was then presented by the student to the community at large. While we strived to provide research skills, we also sought to impart to the students a research mindset that would continue to serve the students. The course was conducted for 3 years consecutively at 5 different sites, Including Montana state university (Bozeman, Mt), Chief Dull Knife College (Lame Deer, Mt), Little Big Horn College (Crow Agency), Fort Peck Community College (Poplar, Mt) and Aaniiih Nakoda College (Fort Belknap, Mt). The course also offers the opportunity to build a network between Montana State University and the surrounding Tribal Colleges in Montana. This network serves to support students as they transition from Tribal Colleges to Montana State University. Last Modified: 03/29/2018 Submitted by: Jennifer B Forecki
